title: Add support for non-zero latitude origin to Bonne.
body:
Most GIS software don't seem to support this, and the formulas only refer to a longitudinal origin (the "central meridian"), presumably because it's trivial.

We could easily have a georotational projection that performs rotations about all three axes, not just z- and y-.  There is an argument for keeping an origin parameter for some projections though, if the maths is simplified.

We don't have an origin parameter for the Mercator projection; I think I used the albers projection as a starting point for Bonne.  So I wouldn't mind dropping the origin parameter from Bonne altogether if you think that's reasonable.  Otherwise, here is a working latitudinal origin!

title: prototypal inheritance between hierarchical objects causes infinite recursive loops due to prototype chain
Minor cleanup of force-cluster example.
body: We don't need to reselect now that appending nodes to the entering selection are automatically added to the updating selection.

title: Add Bonne geographic projection.
body: Note that the Werner projection is a special case with standard parallel at 90°N, and the Sinusoidal projection is also a special case with standard parallel at 0°N.

title: Npm doesn't necessarily install dependencies under d3/node_modules
body: On my system (homebrew 0.8, node.js 0.4.8, npm 0.3.18), "npm install" installs d3's dependencies below /usr/local/lib/node ($NODE_PATH), not d3/node_modules – this tweak should make "make test" work with either configuration.

title: Less zealous click cancelling.
body:
The click event is prevented from propagating when a drag has occurred i.e. the mouse has moved between mousedown and mouseup.  This is because a click event will be triggered after a mousedown and mouseup have occurred on the same element.  However, we were cancelling the next click event _anywhere_, regardless of whether mousedown and mouseup occurred on the same element or not.

As a sanity check, we also check that the click event was triggered on the same element that mousedown _and_ mouseup occurred on, before cancelling it.  Just in case!

title: Append should accept raw nodes (listed as 'todo?' in selection-append.js)
body:
This commit lets you pass raw nodes to append, and includes relevant tests.

One thing that might be confusing to users is that when you give `.appendChild()` a node that is already on the DOM, that node will be moved rather than copied, so when you pass a node to `.append()` it will in effect only append it to the last element in the selection.
I don't expect it will be a problem though, since only advanced users will be passing raw nodes to `.append()`.

title: Fix a bug when charge forces are zero.
body: This was causing a divide by zero in the center-of-charge calculation.

title: Better log ticks.
body: This adds support for filtering the log ticks, such that fewer ticks can be generated to fit in a small space. This can be used in conjunction with a custom tick format as well. This commit also changes the default log tick format to be exponential rather than precision, for consistency.

title: Add si prefix format
body:
This right here's stolen directly from gnuplot, and is something Cube made me want. (thanks for cube, btw!)

This adds the specifier "s" to format numbers into nearest-SI-prefix format- so "127545" -> "128k", "1500" -> "1.5k", etc. Good for dealing with giant counters, and (for me) more natural to read than exponent notation. Currently, this is a slightly deficient implementation in that it (1) completely ignores precision and (2) falls back on its own degenerate representation when |x| > 10^26, but I wanted to at least check in to see if this'd be wanted before spending more time on it.

title: fix sigfig ('r') formatting with precision using zero as input
body: presently this returns NaN due to an attempt at taking the log of zero. i've special-cased it out to just short-circuit to .toPrecision(p) on zero input.

title: Add d3.behavior.select for brush+filter.
body:
This is typically called on an svg:rect element.  Dragging on the element's parent will fire "selectstart", "select" and "selectend" events with d3.event having x, y, dx and dy set appropriately: dx and dy will be updated as the rectangle is sized.  Dragging on the element will also fire these events, but only x and y will be updated while dragging: this is because the rectangle is being moved.

Fixes #248.

title: Fix sort due to lack of NodeList.prototype.sort.
body:
NodeList doesn't support .sort() directly, so we need to convert to a real Array first.  I've done this in selectAll for efficiency i.e. this avoids a new Array being created every time the same selection is sorted.  However, it may be slightly more efficient to create the Array only when sorting, to avoid unnecessary Array creation when sorting isn't used, which is probably the common case.

Unfortunately it's difficult to test this because JSDOM uses a real Array instead of a NodeList!

title: Update tests for d3.layout.pack.
body: Improves the residual floating point error test, and adds a test for coincident circles.

title: Modified d3.csv to include an optional parameter allowing you to specify
body:
Modified d3.csv to include an optional parameter allowing you to specify type of dilimiter as a string - pipe, tab, etc. 

This mimics the behavior of the R function read.csv().

title: add equirectangular projection
body: Straightforward equirectangular projection as an alternative to Mercator.

title: Adding chargeMultiplier to individual points in d3.layout.force
body: I added some code so that the force layout can give different charges to individual nodes. The way to do this is to simply add node.chargeMultiplier (default amounts to 1).

title: Add a ticks function to chart.bullet
body:
The function takes two arguments:
- d:       The data for the bullet chart
- scale:   The x scale for the chart (refered to as x1 in the main
          function)

The default behaviour is to simply call scale.ticks(8) as per the
previous behaviour.

Here's a coffeescript example of how I'm using it. I only want 0 and
useful points on my chart:

```
 .ticks((d, scale) -> _.uniq d3.merge [[0], d.markers, d.measures, d.ranges])
```

title: Add innerRadius and outerRadius to pie layout
body:
I think it makes sense to be able to specify these for the pie chart layout so that one does not need to apply these to the arc.

After all, someone using the pie layout most likely does not want to manipulate the individual arc lengths.

This change also adds default values so that if an inner radius is not set the arc.centroid function does not return NaNs. As cool as donut charts are, I'm sure there are people who may not specify the inner radius and wonder why they can't have labels (as I ran into while learning).

title: Add gnomonic, equidistant and equalarea modes to azimuthal projection.
body: Also, moved d3_radians to src/geo/geo.js.  Perhaps this should be renamed to d3_geo_radians for consistency?

title: Treat nodes with empty children arrays as leaves.
body:
Fixes #286.

I'm not sure if there's anything else we need to test here.  Seems like a pretty straightforward change.

title: Handle zero-valued nodes in d3.layout.pack.
body: Also fixed handling of empty children array.

title: Fix width/height of treemap-svg example.
body: In IE9, using style("width", 960) fails with "SCRIPT87: invalid argument" because strictly speaking, non-zero CSS widths need a unit e.g. "960px".  In SVG, we normally use width/height attributes via attr() instead of the CSS equivalents.

title: Multi-value map support.
body:
Current progress:
- selection.attr - done
- selection.style - done
- selection.property - done
- selection.classed - done
- selection.on - done
- transition.attr - done
- transition.style - done

Also, we may want to include these, but I'm not 100% yet:
- transition.attrTween?
- transition.styleTween?
- transition.tween?

title: Add d3.geo.greatcircle.
body:
Can be used to generate great circle paths.  Similar to R's geosphere.gcIntermediate (in which I discovered a bug, while writing the test case for this!)

Includes d3.geo.greatcircle().distance for computing the shortest geo path distance using the Haversine formula.

For a tutorial on using great circles, see: http://flowingdata.com/2011/05/11/how-to-map-connections-with-great-circles/

title: Style
body:
Style can now take an object or function which returns an object. In these cases, the second argument will set the priority.

treemap.js has an example of the function form.

Not sure the best way of approaching styleTween. I'll send that attempt as a separate pull request.

title: Add invert to mercator, albers and azimuthal.
body: Includes unit tests!

title: Fix KDE example.
body: It should have been using a probability (density) histogram.
